text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) 10.2.8, Incident Reporting.
References to Watch Commander roles and functions have been removed. Role has been made obsolete.
As of January

, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) instituted a requirement that the IRM address relevant internal controls. This will inform employees about the importance of and context internal controls by describing the program objectives and officials charged with program management and oversight. Internal controls are the program’s policies and procedures which

As of January 1, 2017, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) instituted a requirement that the IRM address relevant internal controls. This will inform employees about the importance of and context for internal controls by describing the program objectives and officials charged with program management and oversight. Internal controls are the program’s policies and procedures which

a. Mission and program objectives are clearly delineated and key terms deﬁned. b. Program goals are established and performance is measured to assess the efficient and effective mission and objective accomplishment. c. Program and resources are protected against waste, fraud, abuse, mismanagement and misappropriation. d. Program operations are in conformance with applicable laws and regulations. e. Financial reporting is complete, current and accurate. f. Reliable information is obtained and used for decision making and quality assurance.
Servicewide
Table of Contents

) This IRM section discusses the Situation Awareness Management Center (SAMC) and provides guidance on reporting physical security incidents and and conditions or situations to appropriate authorities and a process for incidents. (

) Purpose: This IRM provides policy and guidance to be used by IRS and organizations including, contractors, vendors, and outsourcing when reporting physical security incidents to the SAMC. Physical security incidents are incidents and/or threats (direct, indirect, implied), office loss of identiﬁcation (ID) media, disruptive/disgruntled taxpayers and personnel. (
) Audience: Servicewide (
) Policy Owner: Chief, Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS) (
) Program Owner: FMSS Associate Director (AD), Security Policy (

) Primary Stakeholders: Senior Commissioner’s Representatives (SCR), ministrative Officers (AO), FMSS AD, FMSS Field Operations Territory Managers (TM), Security Section Chiefs (SSC), Physical Security (PSS), and FMSS Security Policy personnel. (

) Program Goals: To ensure the safety and security of IRS personnel, and infrastructure by providing interactive, proactive and reactive solutions threats or actions against the IRS through the Incident Reporting system. (

) SAMC was created and tasked with promptly reporting all physical security incidents and/or threats. SAMC mission is to document, archive and report incidents, threats, and emergencies. SAMC does this by supporting the Services’ law enforcement partners to ensure the safety of IRS personnel, cilities, and infrastructure. Additionally, SAMC disseminates, documents, responds to inquiries from the Department of the Treasury, governmental agencies and other federal law enforcement partners. This is important as SAMC must be kept apprised of situations that could require the immediate assistance and/or attention, of the IRS Commissioner, Chief, FMSS, and/or other IRS Executives. (
) SAMC is a
operation center and is the focal point for incident SAMC monitors and routes incident reports to the appropriate key IRS personnel. (

) Chief, FMSS is responsible for oversight of security policy and guidance. (
) AD, Security Policy is responsible for oversight of planning, developing, menting, evaluating, and controlling security policy. (
) Chief, Facilities Protection Management (FPM) is responsible for planning, veloping, implementing, evaluating, and controlling security policy. (
) Internal Revenue Manual

Program Goals: To ensure the safety and security of IRS personnel, facilities and infrastructure by providing interactive, proactive and reactive solutions to threats or actions against the IRS through the Incident Reporting system.
Chief, Facilities Protection Management (FPM) is responsible for planning, de- veloping, implementing, evaluating, and controlling security policy.
Physical Security (
) Each FMSS Operations AD and TM are responsible to ensure each SSC follows the IRS policy and provides oversight in the implementation and en- forcement of the SAMC program. (

) SAMC Watch Standers (WS) are responsible for: a. Promptly reporting all incidents and emergencies that result in the to respond to inquiries from the Department of the Treasury or the media to the SAMC Program Manager (PM) and the SSC. Note: Notiﬁcations to the Commissioner of the IRS, Chief, FMSS, other IRS executives are sent to ensure that these individuals kept apprised of situations that could require their immediate tance and/or attention. b. Documenting, reporting and sending notiﬁcations for all incidents and threats Servicewide within the Threat Response Center (TRC) applica- tion. c. Reporting facility closures reported to SAMC to the FMSS SSC and Department of Treasury Operations Center (TOC). Note: This is for all reported facility closures due to any major failures, natural disasters, and acts of nature or severe weather. Reports of closures to SAMC must include: a) Description of the incident b) Facility impacted by the incident c) Number of personnel affected d) Amount of time the facility is expected to be closed e) Actions taken by IRS (

) SAMC PM is responsible for: a. Developing policy and procedures for implementing proper mitigation countermeasures. Note: This ensures that all incidents and threats Servicewide have the proper mitigation and countermeasures in place to ensure the safety of IRS personnel and/or facilities. b. Serving as the Threat and Incident Response Center (TIRC) Chair. c. Maintaining Internal Controls for the SAMC Program. d. Reviewing and approving the daily Leadership View (LV) report that outlines the Level
and Level

Physical Security Incidents along with any Office Closures that occurred on the prior day. e. Ensuring that SAMC program documentation and procedures are date and current (i.e. IRM). f. Establishing and maintaining SAMC processes and training programs. g. Establishing a secure process to receive physical security incidents, to provide guidance to WS on proper classiﬁcation, as needed. h. Taking appropriate and prompt corrective action when an imminent incident or threat occurs. i. Reviewing and providing recommendations when existing countermea- sures require modiﬁcation to ensure the safety of personnel and and follow up when required. j. Maintaining and updating procedures and communications for the programs: Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) The SSC is responsible for: a. Serving as the physical security personnel monitoring all incidents and threats within their geographical coverage area, to (aid) assist in ing the validity of the data reported. b. Accessing incidents to ensure reported incidents are properly through established protocols and countermeasures. c. Submitting the Follow Up Incident Report (FUIR). Note: All incidents that have been classiﬁed as a level
incident threat requires a FUIR. Note: The FUIR must be submitted to SAMC within

, SAMC Reporting, annually. e. Providing updates on incidents to the FMSS TM, FMSS AD, TIRC/SAMC PM, and the SAMC WS until the incidents are completed and/or terminated. Note: Any incident requiring the evacuation or closing of an IRS facility due to an impending threat, either natural or man-made is ered signiﬁcant. In addition to SAMC, the SSC must also report signiﬁcant incidents immediately to the FMSS TM, and AD by telephone. This initial notiﬁcation is intended to provide warning of impending threats and/or situations. (
) SCR/AO is responsible for reporting facility closures affected by any major equipment failures, natural disasters, acts of nature or severe weather.
a. Serving as the physical security personnel monitoring all incidents and threats within their geographical coverage area, to (aid) assist in identify

ing the validity of the data reported. b. Accessing incidents to ensure reported incidents are properly addressed through established protocols and countermeasures. c. Submitting the Follow Up Incident Report (FUIR).
Note: All incidents that have been classiﬁed as a level 1 incident and/or threat requires a FUIR.
Note: The FUIR must be submitted to SAMC within 24 hours of occur- rence.

) All IRS Personnel are responsible for: a. Familiarizing themselves with the physical security incident and emergency reporting procedures. Note: All physical security incidents must be reported to the SAMC
minutes of incident discovery, or when it is safe to do so.
Note: All physical security incidents must be reported to the SAMC within 30 minutes of incident discovery, or when it is safe to do so.
Note: For additional information, see ELMS Course 71555, SAMC Incident Reporting.
Physical Security (

) Program Reports: a. Analysis of reported incident data conducted monthly, quarterly and and annually. Data is derived from the TRC database. b. Quarterly performance reviews to assess WS accuracy and timeliness processing incident notiﬁcations. c. Prepare Daily LV reports of high level incidents reported the previous workday. (
) Program Effectiveness: Accurate and complete notiﬁcations to appropriate personnel as outlined in training materials. (
) Internal Control - Random Sampling Process – ensures that the WS are complying with the
-minute timeframe for incident processing within the application. (
) Criminal Investigation - An IRS organization that is the law enforcement of the IRS with investigative jurisdiction. (
) Direct Threat - A direct expression of intention to inﬂict evil, injury, or at the IRS. (

) Federal Protective Service (FPS) - An organization within the Department Homeland Security (DHS) that protects federal facilities, their occupants, visitors by providing law enforcement and protective security services. (
) Follow Up Incident Report (FUIR) - Report generated and prepared by Impacted SSC and used by the TIRC-IRC to outline the actions taken to mitigate the reported incident/threat. (
) Guard - A Protective Security Officer (PSO) who is contracted to protect personnel and IRS facilities in addition to deter security incidents. (
) Incident - An occurrence of an action or situation, such as an act of human intervention or an act of nature (i.e. storm or ﬁre) that requires a physical security response. (
) Indirect Threat - An implied threat with expression of intention to inﬂict evil, injury, or damage and is not directly aimed at the IRS. (
) Individual - The person who is the subject of an incident with no known to the IRS. (
) Information Technology (IT) Cybe

ecurity - IT security service provider sponsible for ensuring IRS compliance with federal statutory, legislative and regulatory requirements governing conﬁdentiality, integrity and availability of IRS electronic systems, services and data. (
) Infrastructure - The basic equipment and structures (such as phones, electricity and buildings) that are needed for the IRS to function properly. (
) Level

Incident - Incidents involving a direct threat of an imminent assault action against identiﬁable IRS personnel (in relation to a known or implied nexus to their employment, facilities, or infrastructure). Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
P

Analysis of reported incident data conducted monthly, quarterly and annually. Data is derived from the TRC database. Quarterly performance reviews to assess WS accuracy and timeliness in processing incident notiﬁcations. Prepare Daily LV reports of high level incidents reported the previous workday.
- A Protective Security Officer (PSO) who is contracted to protect and IRS facilities in addition to deter security incidents.
Incident - An occurrence of an action or situation, such as an act of intervention or an act of nature (i.e. storm or ﬁre) that requires a physical
Infrastructure - The basic equipment and structures (such as phones, desks, electricity and buildings) that are needed for the IRS to function properly.
page (
) Level

Incident - Incidents involving an indirect threat against IRS facilities, or resources. These are generally not imminent threats but may potential for triggering future actions and/or elevating to a Level
Incident. (
) Level
Incident - Incidents involving minimal security or management ment, security exercises, and loss or stolen ID media. (
) Personnel - refers to IRS employees and contractors. (
) Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD) - An IRS organiza- tion whose mission is to protect the sensitive information and privacy of taxpayers and personnel. (
) Protective Security Officer - PSO (i.e. Guards) who are contracted to offices for threats and to deter incidents from occurring within IRS facilities. (
) Situation Awareness Management Center (SAMC) Program Manager - FMSS employee responsible for establishing program objectives and technical direction for SAMC operations. (
) Security Section Chief (SSC) - An FMSS Operations manager responsible physical security within a geographical area. (
) Security Exercises - Security awareness drills such as Shelter-in-Place, Fire Drill, and Active Shooter. (
) SAMC - A
program within FMSS responsible for incident and threat reporting servicewide. The SAMC also serves as the central point for all incident communications and notiﬁcations. (
) Stakeholder - IRS business unit or individual responsible for security and/or with a need to know. (
) Taxpayer Assistance Center (TAC) - An IRS location that provides with tax assistance face-to-face. (
) Threat - A person or thing likely to cause damage or danger. (
) Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration - A Treasury that is committed to the prevention and detection of fraud, waste, and abuse within the IRS and related entities. (
) TIGTA Incident Notiﬁcation Submittal (TINS) - Incidents submitted by to SAMC. (

) Threat and Incident Response Center (TIRC) - Group that monitors and reviews incidents and threats to the IRS. Stakeholder organizations, FMSS, TIGTA, Criminal Investigation (CI), PGLD, IT Cyber Security, and FPS. (
) Threat Response Center (TRC) - Database software application used by the Watch Standers to manage all incident and threats reported to SAMC. (
) Watch Stander (WS) - The SAMC individual responsible for documenting updating incidents servicewide. (
) WS Lead - Supervisor of the WS.
Level 3 Incident - Incidents involving minimal security or management involve- ment, security exercises, and loss or stolen ID media.
Protective Security Officer - PSO (i.e. Guards) who are contracted to monitor offices for threats and to deter incidents from occurring within IRS facilities.
TIGTA Incident Notiﬁcation Submittal (TINS) - Incidents submitted by TIGTA
Threat Response Center (TRC) - Database software application used by the Watch Standers to manage all incident and threats reported to SAMC.

) All IRS personnel must report any physical security incidents to the SAMC within
minutes of incident discovery/identiﬁcation, or when it is safe to do so. (
) Incidents involving the inadvertent unauthorized disclosure of PII or of Privacy Act information must be reported to PGLD. Note: For additional information, see IRM
, Privacy and Information Protec- tion, Incident Management Program, for detailed information. (
) Incidents involving the loss or theft of IT assets must be reported to Cybe
e- curity. Note: For additional information, see IRM
, Information Technology (IT) Security, Policy and Guidance. (

) Any incident requiring the evacuation or closing of an IRS facility due to an impending threat, either natural or man-made is considered signiﬁcant. In addition to SAMC, FMSS TM and/or SSC must also report signiﬁcant immediately to the Chief, FMSS by telephone. This initial notiﬁcation is intended to provide forewarning of impending threats and/or situations. (

) Threats against or assaults on IRS personnel and facilities are also required be reported to the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA). TIGTA is the only investigative agency with jurisdiction to investigate internal and external attempts to interfere with tax administration as outlined in RRA

) A list of incidents that must be reported to SAMC is provided in Exhibit

, Incidents to be Reported to SAMC. The list of incidents is not all inclusive but will help provide a basis for determining which incidents must reported. Note: For additional guidance, contact SAMC if you are unsure as to whether to report an incident. When there is doubt as to whether an incident or should not be reported, the incident should be reported to the SAMC. It is the employee’s obligation and responsibility to report security incidents through the prescribed IRS incident reporting process, even if in- structed not to report by an investigative agency. (
) There may be incidents not listed in Exhibit

, but may be considered sensitive or high proﬁle. When there is doubt as to whether an incident should or should not be reported, the incident should be reported to SAMC. The WS will consult with the TIRC/SAMC Program Manager for guidance. (

) When reporting incidents to the SAMC or to the local FMSS physical security staff, at a minimum, the following information must be provided: a. Time and date of incident b. Name of facility/office c. Address of facility/office d. Details of what occurred (who, what, when, where, how, and if possible why) e. Who was notiﬁed (FPS, TIGTA, local authorities, senior management, etc.) f. Approximate number of IRS personnel affected g. Whether the facility has been evacuated or closed (including the of downtime minutes/hours) h. POC or an individual at the facility in the event there are follow up questions (
) Incident Reporting Form (SAMC website portal) at: a. https://tscc.enterprise.irs.gov/irc/ b. telephone at

e. e-mail samc@irs.gov Note: Although it is not always possible, the website portal is the preferred method for reporting incidents to the SAMC.

When reporting incidents to the SAMC or to the local FMSS physical security staff, at a minimum, the following information must be provided:

Name of facility/office Address of facility/office Details of what occurred (who, what, when, where, how, and if possible why) Who was notiﬁed (FPS, TIGTA, local authorities, senior management, etc.) Approximate number of IRS personnel affected Whether the facility has been evacuated or closed (including the of downtime minutes/hours) POC or an individual at the facility in the event there are follow up questions
Note: Although it is not always possible, the website portal is the preferred method for reporting incidents to the SAMC.
Reporting
page (

) Various types of incident notiﬁcations will be sent to local FMSS physical security staff, and designated response personnel with responsibilities to receive incident and threat notiﬁcations from SAMC identiﬁed by their unit. Designated response personnel will be responsible for forwarding the incident/threat to the responsible party within their business unit, if applicable. (

) Requests for SAMC reports and incident information is based on a need to know. Due to the sensitivity of some information, incidents will not be nated or disclosed from SAMC outside of FMSS and/or TIGTA/Law Enforcement. Email requests for incident information must be sent to the SAMC Program Managers. (

) Personnel identiﬁed for their role in security matters or Human Capital Office (HCO) Continuity of Operations Program (COOP) organization within the IRS will be notiﬁed of incidents and/or threats as warranted to ensure the safety IRS personnel, facilities and infrastructure. (
) Daily notiﬁcation of Level
and

physical security incidents with an impact the service from the previous work day will be distributed through the LV Report. The LV report is distributed to designated personnel (executives, managers and other personnel).
This Page Intentionally Left Blank
INCIDENTS TO BE REPORTED TO SAMC

This list encompasses examples of situations that should be reported to SAMC. The list includes examples of incidents and/or threats (direct, indirect, implied), office closures, loss of ID media, disruptive/disgruntled taxpayers and personnel. This list does not encompass all incidents and can change as threats to the IRS change. When there is doubt as to whether an incident should be reported to SAMC, the incident should be reported.

list encompasses examples of situations that should be reported to SAMC. The list includes of incidents and/or threats (direct, indirect, implied), office closures, loss of ID media, taxpayers and personnel. This list does not encompass all incidents and can as threats to the IRS change. When there is doubt as to whether an incident should be to SAMC, the incident should be reported.
INCIDENT
Alarm activations (duress, ﬁre and perimeter)
Arson or a ﬁre with injury or a disruption of IRS operations
Exercises (ﬁre drills, evacuation drills, SIP drills, table top
Inﬂuenza (FLU) - Illness has spread to multiple people having an impact on the IRS
(Loss of remittance with PII disclosed should be reported to PGLD. For additional information, see IRM 21.3.4, Taxpayer Contacts, Field Assistance.)
Loss or compromise of Classiﬁed Information (National Security Information)
Loss or theft of building access card, building or room keys, legacy ID card, pocket commissions, SMART ID, government property or equipment, sensitive data
Parasitic invasion (examples: bed bugs, lice, tick, mice, etc.)
Possession (illegal)/discovery of a controlled substance
Statements by individuals of support of violence to IRS employees and/or
INCIDENTS TO BE REPORTED TO SAMC
Statements by individuals of sympathy with radical groups

Suicide threats - nexus to an IRS facility (by employee or taxpayer when an overt or implied threat is made toward the safety of employees or an IRS facility - whether they can carry out the threat or not)
Suspicious activity (photographing or surveillances of IRS property; Non-nexus related at Federal Buildings or IRS shared locations)
Suspicious packages (resulting in a disruption of IRS operations or negative ﬁnding)
Theft - of government property, personal property, a lockbox, tax remittance
Unsecured property or facility
Vehicle accidents on government property (with or without injuries)
Verbal/written threat (involving an employee or taxpayer)
violence - Physical altercation between employees or between an employee and a taxpayer
